Background.text: Fracture of the 4th or 5th metacarpal caused by an axial load, typically from punching a person or object

Clinical_Features.text:
Pain or swelling along the 4th or 5th metacarpals
Volar angulation of metacarpal or "missing 4th/5th knuckle"
Look for areas of skin breakdown which may signify a fight bite that can result in a
closed fist infection
if untreated

Diagnosis.text:
Typically on plain hand x-ray showing fracture of the 4th or 5th metacarpal
"Uncomplicated"
Defined as:
Minimally displaced
Closed
Isolated injury
Fracture angulation of <70 degrees

General_Fracture_Management.text:
Acute pain management
Open fractures
require immediate IV antibiotics and urgent surgical washout
Neurovascular compromise from fracture requires emergent reduction and/or orthopedic intervention
Consider risk for
compartment syndrome

Acute_Reduction.text:
Contingent upon angulation and rotation
Any rotational deformity should be reduced to allow proper hand function (seen as scissoring)
Angulation >30° in the 4th digit or >40° in the 5th digit should be reduced
Video
on how to perform reduction

Immobilization.text:
See Diagnosis section for definition
Uncomplicated
Buddy taping
[1]
Similar functional outcomes those randomized to plaster cast with earlier return to work
[2]
Similar satisfaction and pain control as those randomized to plaster casting
[3]
Shorter ER Stay
[4]
Complicated:
Forearm volar splint
with extension over the head of the MCP joint provides equal effect and is better tolerated
[5]
Classically, the
Ulnar Gutter Splint
was recommended

Indications_for_Subsequent_Out-Patient_O.text:
Intra-articular fracture
Rotational malalignment of digit
Significantly displaced or angulated fractures (see above criteria)
Multiple metacarpal shaft fractures
Loss of stability from border digit during healing process
